head.title: Democrats Rake It In; G.O.P. Makes Hay

hedline.hl1: Democrats Rake It In; G.O.P. Makes Hay

block.p: Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, headlined a star-spangled musical benefit for the Democratic Party that was sponsored by three top entertainment executives, a move that Republicans said undercut recent Democratic criticism of the industry's marketing practices.

The event in Manhattan, which featured some of the best-known names in popular music, raised $6.5 million for the Democratic National Committee. But because its organizers included Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax Films, the bounty was not gathered without some political cost.

Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, headlined a star-spangled musical benefit for the Democratic Party that was sponsored by three top entertainment executives, a move that Republicans said undercut recent Democratic criticism of the industry's marketing practices.

The event in Manhattan, which featured some of the best-known names in popular music, raised $6.5 million for the Democratic National Committee. But because its organizers included Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax Films, the bounty was not gathered without some political cost.

Hours before the concert began in Radio City Music Hall, the Republican national chairman, Jim Nicholson, stood outside the hall and accused the Democrats of hypocrisy. He said it was disingenuous for Mr. Gore to take the entertainment industry's money days after harshly criticizing it for marketing violent films, recordings and video games to children.
